  sgcool_label_text: Tirukkural
 authored by the sage Tiruvalluvar and dating to the 5th-6th century
 is considered one of the greatest works of Tamil writing. The text
 divided into 133 chapters of 10 couplets each
 covers a wide range of topics pertaining to morality
 behaviour and the human condition. From the 12th century
 in the tradition of Indian literary discourse
 various commentaries have been written on Tirukurral
 more so than for any other Tamil text. This is a 19th century copy of Tirukkural with annotated commentary
 further highlighting how important the text continued to be even up to the modern period.

metadata.physical_appearance: This is a classical Tamil text called Tirukkural. It is a collection of inscriptions on thin panels, held together by a string through two holds in the middle of each segment.
metadata.subject_terms_1: religious texts Tamil (culture or style) inscriptions ethics (philosophy)

metadata.sgcool_label_text: Tirukkural, authored by the sage Tiruvalluvar and dating to the 5th-6th century, is considered one of the greatest works of Tamil writing. The text, divided into 133 chapters of 10 couplets each, covers a wide range of topics pertaining to morality, behaviour and the human condition. From the 12th century, in the tradition of Indian literary discourse, various commentaries have been written on Tirukurral, more so than for any other Tamil text. This is a 19th century copy of Tirukkural with annotated commentary, further highlighting how important the text continued to be even up to the modern period.
